awd_titl_txt: REU Site:  Interdisciplinary Research Experiences in Coastal Plain Science
awd_abstract_narration:
This REU Site award to Georgia Southern University (GSU), located in Statesboro, GA, will support the training of 10 students for 10 weeks during the summers of 2019-2021. Housed at GSU's Institute for Coastal Plain Science, the unifying theme involves the impacts of global climate change stressors on organisms and ecosystems of the Atlantic Coastal Plain. The goal is to engage undergraduates in research and professional development activities that promote an understanding of the unique physical and biological resources occurring in this geographic region as well as their sustainable use and management. Students will participate in hands-on research guided by faculty mentors, as well as in professional development workshops targeting general and conceptual knowledge in the ecology and geology of the coastal plain, scientific communication skills (oral and written), techniques for locating and evaluating primary literature, and ethical practices in science. 

It is anticipated that a total of 30 students will be trained in the program. Recruitment is targeted at 1st and 2nd year (freshman/sophomore) students attending institutions in the southeastern U.S. where research opportunities may be more limited, such as at 2-year colleges and primarily undergraduate institutions. Students from underrepresented groups that comprise a large percentage of the population in the region are especially encouraged to apply. Students will learn how research is conducted, and many will present the results of their work at scientific conferences. The goal is to foster an environment for learning and professional development that leads to opportunities in graduate studies and careers in science. 

A common web-based assessment tool used by all REU Site programs funded by the Division of Biological Infrastructure will be used to determine the effectiveness of the training program. Students will be tracked after the program in order to determine their career paths. Students will be asked to respond to an automatic email sent via the NSF reporting system. More information about the program is available by visiting http://cosm.georgiasouthern.edu/icps/REU/, or by contacting the PI (Dr. J. Checo Colon-Gaud at jccolongaud@georgiasouthern.edu) or the co-PI (Dr. Danny Gleason at dgleason@georgiasouthern.edu).

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The REU Site Interdisciplinary Research Experiences in Coastal Plain Science engaged undergraduates in research and professional development activities that promote an understanding of the unique physical and biological resources occurring in the Atlantic Coastal Plain geographic region as well as their sustainable use and management. A total of 30 undergaduate students and 2 postbaccalaureate fellows were funded through the program, received research and professional skill development training and participated in mentored research. At the conclusion of each cohort, participants presented original research as part of an end of program symposium. Many program participants also presented the results of the work completed during their time in the program at local, regional, national and international conferences. A major goal of the program is to prepare participants for for careers in research. Several of the previous program participants pursued graduate studies following the completion of the undergraduate degree and some are employed in positions with an active research component. The program supported numerous students from groups that are traditionally under-represented in STEM fields, including students from community colleges, primarily undergraduate institutions (PUI), and minority serving institutions (MSI). Standard assessments of student learning gains following participation in the program showed that students perceived achieving great gains (>50%) in their problem solving skills, in formulating research questions that can be answered with data, and in understanding the limitations of research methods and study designs, all which can be associated to the application of knowledge to research work and thinking and working as a scientists. Program participants also indicated good gains in personal skills and expressed a positive outlook from the research experience. Opportunities to participate in hands-on research experiences, like the ones provided through the program, can play an important role in the career choices of students. One of the program's primary goals was to make an impact in teaching and education practices by providing experiential opportunities that exposed participants to the research process and the unique needs for conservation and management of natural resources in the Coastal Plain region. During the award period, participants engaged with scientists at research facilities, conservation areas, a national wildlife refuge, and a long-term ecological research site. Continued exposure to these resources and career opportunities in the field incorporating such sites and facilities as part of the teaching and learning environment are likely to make an impact on the continued development of participants.
